It was the beef roads scheme that gave me the sort of inflow of business which enabled me to have a very successful business in that part of outback Western Queensland where jobs and opportunities in business were very hard to come by indeed. I wanted to stay home and live in Cloncurry, and that was about the only opportunity available to me. That opportunity was created by the great men who were in this
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Katter (Kennedy) (12.55 P.m.)
theText: I would like to return to what I was speaking about14982 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 16 March 2000 place at that time. We can very easily reinstitute that greatness if we adopt this recommendation in the report. I pay a very fine tribute to all the committee members who put this report together. In addition, sometimes people say-and it is becoming a bit fashionable in the press to say it too-that we enjoy great subsidies in country areas. As to where all this economic rationalism came from, Mr Hilmer did a report on road transport in Australia and he pointed out that there was a $4,000 million a year subsidy provided to urban transportation systems. This committee heard evidence that that $4,000 million had blown out to $6,000 million a year in annual subsidies, and the tiny amount of money we are talking about here pales into insignificance when you compare the two amounts. (Time expired) Western Australia: Truck Drivers Ms GERICK (Canning) (1.00 p.m.)-If the tyranny of distance applies to Australia, then that tyranny is at this moment being most sharply felt by the communities in the north-west of Australia. Presently in the north of Western Australia there are a number of areas devastated by floodwaters, effectively isolating these communities from the rest of the state. It is reported that the Fitzroy River is expected to peak at 16 metres later this week, with no indication that water levels will subside at any time soon. You need only to read the newspaper to see that the damage has been extensive. Homes, businesses, livestock and food crops have been destroyed. The damage is not isolated to these areas alone. In the long term, we all know that the impact of this natural disaster will have far-reaching consequences beyond the areas currently affected. Past experience has shown that when the demand for fresh produce exceeds ready supply, the flow-on effect of this to the communities is felt at the cash register. Provision of fresh food items such as bananas, which Carnarvon is well known for, will simply not be available, and it is expected that supply will be severely affected for up to 18 months. It has been reported that in Kununurra alone, residents are experiencing severe shortages of essential food items such as meat, milk and vegetables. It is not known how long this disruption will continue. How many transport workers are cut off from their families and have had their means of income severely reduced? The latest report is that at least 200 truck drivers are currently stranded because of raging floodwaters. It is reported that some drivers have been stranded for up to 16 days and have been forced to live off the produce on the backs of their trucks and from community handouts. They are being forced to live without adequate toilet facilities and are facing the real threat of mosquito-borne viruses. We are all aware that truck drivers provide a crucial service to the isolated communities in the north-west with the provision of essential goods. You name it-food, medical supplies, housing, fuel, beer, everything. Without truckies there can be no mining, agriculture, farming, or any other kind of industry in these remote areas. The wheels of their huge trucks might not be turning but drivers are still incurring the ongoing costs of running their businesses. It is estimated that in some cases drivers are still meeting costs of up to $2,000 per week for truck repayments and insurance alone. Without any means of income, one cannot imagine how much longer their businesses will survive. There is already confusion, concern and speculation about how the GST will affect the transport industry. This government’s lack of concise information to the community about the full effects of the GST is concern enough for these battlers without the added pressure and concern brought about by this natural disaster. The Western Australian state government has Thursday, 16 March 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 14983 indicated that assistance will be offered to the Carnarvon region for specific flood relief, and has also promised long-term action to reduce flooding. It is well known that the federal government collects 36c in every dollar from fuel excise. It is time for the government to return some of this income by way of emergency financial assistance to those truck drivers stranded by the unpredictable floodwaters. It is without question that our truckies are the backbone of the nation. Without them, the wheels of our community would not turn. It is this government’s responsibility to step in now and provide much needed assistance to the drivers and their families. In times of crisis it is surely not unreasonable for these vital members of our community to expect and depend on the assistance of their state and federal governments. Primary Industries and Regional Services Committee Report previously-the report entitled Time running out: shaping regional Australia’s future. The subsidisation of city commuter transportation systems has now reached the level of $6 billion. Evidence was presented to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Primary Industries and Regional Services to this effect. Let us talk about subsidies. The cities get $6 billion, and there is nothing that you can point to that can come remotely close to that sort of figure. In addition to that, I took the top 20 export items to give me some idea of where our export earnings were coming from, and 94 per cent of our export earnings were coming from the mining and agricultural sector. One of the great recommendations in this document-along with the 2c per litre, which is of such vital value and importance to us-was that we move departments into regional areas. When we say ‘regional areas’ there seems to be some sort of an idea that we give something to a place like Townsville. Townsville, quite frankly, does not need a pest and weed research station. It means absolutely nothing to that community. Why you would put a research station for weeds and agricultural pests in Townsville, where there is no farming or agriculture whatsoever, is quite beyond the wildest stretch of my imagination. After 2¾ years of battling, we got the then Queensland government to site that research centre in Charters Towers. Thirty new jobs in Charters Towers means an awful lot to that community. In addition to that, every day of the week-whether it is at the P&C or the Lions Club or at church-those people interface with people who are coming to grips with the Acacia nilotica tree, rubber vine and Harrisia cactus problems. So they are socially interacting with the people who are going to pressure them to do the right thing and also the people who can provide them with information which is so vitally needed. It is unreal. One of the great reasons for poor government in Australia is that all of the agricultural industry departments are based in huge cities, completely away from the areas that they are supposed to interface with. The decision makers are remote in every sense of the word. They are not where they should be. An honourable member on the other side spoke earlier about the cost of education. We have gone from a situation where the government picked up the entire cost of secondary education in Queensland in the last year of the Bjelke-Petersen government. It was $6,000, and the whole $6,000 was paid by the state and federal governments. That figure has now decreased to $5,000, and the cost of boarding colleges in Charters Towers has moved up to $9,000. So we have a gap here now of $4,000 or $5,000, with transport and everything added. It is impossible for these people-unless they are rich or they get some special access to Aboriginal grants or something of that nature-to get an education.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Katter (Kennedy) (1.05 P.m.)
theText: I want to return to the subject. I was speaking about14984 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 16 March 2000 Moving on, the problems experienced by the sugar industry in the rural areas, which the member for Dawson and I represent, would not be problems if we had development banks. The late and great Black Jack McEwen introduced the primary industries bank, the AIDC bank. I think we would largely attribute to him the Commonwealth Development Bank, as we have known it over the last two or three decades. Government can secure money at a rate of five per cent interest at the present moment. There is no reason why they cannot pass that money on to people when the interest rate is 5½ per cent. I am not asking for it for my trawler men, who have been put under threat by the environment minister’s incredibly unbelievable and callous actions of the present moment, because they have no security value. The sugar farmers, on the other hand, have wonderful security value for a loan. So it is very safe to lend them money. If they can be loaned money with a five per cent interest rate, they will survive. In fact, a lousy $10 million subsidy on top of that, which would go back to the taxpayers instead of to the banks, would reduce that interest rate to 2½ per cent. I think almost every single one of our sugar farmers would pull through. At the present moment it is very doubtful whether even two-thirds of them are going to survive the current situation. This is the first time in 80 years that that industry has been asked to face up to the cyclical downturn, which they have regularly, without a development bank in place. You subsidise our loans at two per cent. What use is that to us? We are paying 11 per cent at the present moment. You are going to die on nine per cent interest rates. (Time expired) Four Corners: Treatment of Asylum Seekers last Monday evening’s ABC Four Corners investigation of the Howard government’s treatment of asylum seekers. It is my view that every member of this House should feel quite ashamed by the revelations contained in Monday evening’s program. It was a very serious program, dealing with four very serious issues. It dealt with mandatory detention of asylum seekers, a system that locks up all illegal arrivals, and locks up their children too. It locks them up for an indefinite time while their claims are being processed. It dealt with the contracting out of the deportation procedures to the private sector, in this case to a company called Australasian Correctional Management which is a subsidiary of the American multinational, Wackenhut, which operates prisons on the east coast of Australia and, indeed, across the world. The program dealt with the forcible and repeated administration of sedatives to asylum seekers, and it also dealt with the housing of asylum seekers in prisons in circumstances where no crime had been committed or has even been alleged. It is with regret that I note the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs shows every sign of delighting in a draconian attitude of harshness and strictness in his approach to the often most tragic circumstances of these asylum seekers. This Four Corners expose on Monday night was deeply disturbing not only for the evidence presented of serious violations of human rights but also for its revelation of the immigration minister’s belligerent defence of the appalling practices of his officials and the private sector contractors who now play such a key role in dealing with deportation cases. Australia unfortunately has an immigration minister who rarely, if ever, uses the terms ‘compassion’ or ‘humanitarian concern’ as part of his dialogue. Instead, it seems to me, there is always an eye to an appeal to the former supporters of Pauline Hanson and her One Nation party. The Four Corners program raises issues of fundamental human rights. Australia for our part is duty bound to speak up in defence of human rights and political freedoms overseas. That is our responsibility. But one has to observe that our ability to do so is irredeemably compromised when people fleeing from human rights abuse in their own countries are so often subjected to what can only be described as a form of institutionalised persecution here in
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Brereton (Kingsford
theText: Smith) (1.10 p.m.)-I rise this afternoon to speak briefly onThursday, 16 March 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 14985 Australia. The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs clearly prides himself on his zealous defence of his system. What a pity he cannot be as zealous in defending basic human rights and their application to those who come here seeking to escape persecution. The Four Corners program is to be warmly congratulated for this most revealing look at Minister Ruddock’s regime. It is a tragedy that the broader media have not paid more attention to this issue. I sincerely hope that this ABC program will prick the consciences of a great many people and encourage further investigative reporting. Beaudesert Heritage Tourist Rail Boonah Economic Development Institute regional Australia in downturn. While there are some areas that are doing it tough, others are clearly going from strength to strength, especially with the support of the Howard government. I want to share with this House this afternoon very positive good news stories about regional centres in my electorate of Forde. These are stories about the innovation and determination of local residents. I am pleased to say that the Howard government has given local residents their full backing, putting much needed funds into getting these projects off the ground. The first is the heritage tourist steam train from Bethania to Beaudesert. The railway line from Bethania to Beaudesert has not been operating for passengers for many years. In 1995, Queensland Rail disconnected freight services on this line. Since long before that, the local residents have been pushing for the line to be reopened to passenger services. This beautiful rural part of south-east Queensland has increasingly become a tourist destination, especially with the nationally recognised Country and Horse Festival in Beaudesert over the past few years. The shire is rapidly developing its tourist industry and recognising that this is a vital way of boosting local businesses and creating more jobs. The Beaudesert Shire Railway Support Group has put together a comprehensive plan to get a tourist steam train operating along this line. I am delighted that earlier this month, when the Treasurer was visiting Forde, we were able to announce that the project had been granted $76,500 in RAP funding from the Howard government to finally get the wheels moving along this track. I want to sincerely thank the local residents who have worked so extremely hard towards this goal and all the members of the railway support group, especially Jim Daynes, who put the submission together. The Treasurer commented how professional that submission was. I would also like to thank Jim for his tireless efforts in working within our community. This project has been greeted with much enthusiasm and optimism by local residents and there is enormous community support to help make this line a success. There was a double celebration when the Treasurer came to my electorate because he then visited the rural town of Boonah and announced that they also had received a grant, of $80,000, to develop the Boonah Economic Development Institute over the next two years. Last October the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, opened the inaugural Boonah Economic Development Institute, a dynamic conference with delegates from all around Australia and New Zealand. It was a thrill to the townspeople to have so many people come and to have their town on display at that time. The conference delegates came together to share the ways that rural towns and regional centres can be revitalised. The institute is based on the very successful Nebraska rural institute concept. Last year’s institute was an enormous success and showcased the can-do attitude of the Boonah community, which is a truly shining example for rural communities throughout Australia. With the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mrs Elson (Forde) (1.15 P.m.)
theText: The media in this country all too often paint a picture of14986 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 16 March 2000 institute, Boonah is not only creating a brand new industry but also helping rural communities around the nation in the process. I want to thank everyone involved in the institute-the Chamber of Commerce, the Boonah council, especially the mayor, John Brent, and also a very special lady in town who works on a number of projects in Boonah, and that is Wendy Creighton. This is a very dynamic and innovative project and I am delighted that my personal support has been backed by the Howard government’s funding. These two projects are an example of how the Howard government is helping rural communities to help themselves. We want to support the revitalisation of our towns, but we know that it is not just about throwing money around. It is about backing local groups who know the areas best and are passionate about making projects work. It is a common sense approach which is beginning to show results. I look forward to continuing to work with local communities throughout Forde to make these and other similar projects successful. I would also like to place on record the enormous amount of work that Deputy Prime Minister John Anderson does in rural Australia. I know he visits many towns. As I said, he has visited my area of Forde and he has promised to come back in the very near future. Our community groups within our rural areas are being innovative with our support and they do not want our bush people thinking that they are recipients of public money unnecessarily. They are equally appreciative of the confidence that we place in them. We do not actually tell them what to do. They show us what rural towns need and we are backing that support 100 per cent. Main Committee adjourned at 1.20 p.m.
title: Representatives Main Committee
